head.title: Experiences Vary Widely For Biracial Children

hedline.hl1: Experiences Vary Widely For Biracial Children

block.p: Although our city is thought of as a melting pot, New Yorkers, like all Americans, have to learn to accept a growing segment of the population -- the children of biracial and multiracial marriages. It's a shame that in this day and age mixed families must endure stares and rude comments and biracial children have to answer questions about their heritage from curious strangers.

Although our city is thought of as a melting pot, New Yorkers, like all Americans, have to learn to accept a growing segment of the population -- the children of biracial and multiracial marriages. It's a shame that in this day and age mixed families must endure stares and rude comments and biracial children have to answer questions about their heritage from curious strangers.

Yet, sometimes, out of the mouths of babes come the gems that put us all in our place. I think Trevor Sage-EL says it best -- he's the biracial (black/white) 10-year-old I interviewed for my children's book, ''Trevor's Story: Growing Up Biracial'' (Lerner Publications). When someone asks Trevor, ''What are you?'' he answers, ''Human.''
